articles.headline: Trump Media Stock Plunges 18%, Extending Recent Losses
articles.snippet: Funds that bet on a fall were set to profit as the parent of Truth Social came under renewed pressure after it registered new shares for a potential sale.
articles.abstract: Funds that bet on a fall were set to profit as the parent of Truth Social came under renewed pressure after it registered new shares for a potential sale.
articles.lead_paragraph: Shares of former President Donald J. Trump’s social media company plunged on Monday after the company filed to register the potential sale of tens of millions of additional shares.
articles.byline: By Matthew Goldstein and Joe Rennison

articles.headline: New Migrants Get Work Permits. Other Undocumented Immigrants Want Them, Too.
articles.snippet: Long-term undocumented immigrants — and their employers — are feeling left out by Biden administration policies allowing most who just crossed the border to work legally.
articles.abstract: Long-term undocumented immigrants — and their employers — are feeling left out by Biden administration policies allowing most who just crossed the border to work legally.
articles.lead_paragraph: Sam Sanchez, a Chicago restaurateur, was incensed when President Biden announced last September that his administration would extend work eligibility to nearly half a million Venezuelans, many of them migrants who had recently crossed the border illegally.
articles.byline: By Miriam Jordan and Lydia DePillis

articles.headline: Johnson Says House Will Vote on Stalled Aid to Israel and Ukraine
articles.snippet: The speaker, who has delayed for months amid G.O.P. opposition to funding for Kyiv, said he would bring up foreign aid legislation along with a bill aimed at appeasing Republican skeptics.
articles.abstract: The speaker, who has delayed for months amid G.O.P. opposition to funding for Kyiv, said he would bring up foreign aid legislation along with a bill aimed at appeasing Republican skeptics.
articles.lead_paragraph: Speaker Mike Johnson on Monday said he planned this week to advance a long-stalled national security spending package to aid Israel, Ukraine and other American allies, along with a separate bill aimed at mollifying conservatives who have been vehemently opposed to backing Kyiv.
articles.byline: By Catie Edmondson, Kayla Guo and Carl Hulse

articles.headline: Israel Weighs Response to Iran’s Attack as Allies Push for Restraint
articles.snippet: The Israeli war cabinet met again on Monday to discuss the strike, with some hawkish members of the prime minister’s government calling for a swift and forceful retaliation.
articles.abstract: The Israeli war cabinet met again on Monday to discuss the strike, with some hawkish members of the prime minister’s government calling for a swift and forceful retaliation.
articles.lead_paragraph: Follow live updates on Israeli military strikes in Iran.
articles.byline: By Cassandra Vinograd, Isabel Kershner and Michael Levenson

articles.headline: China’s Economy, Propelled by Its Factories, Grew More Than Expected
articles.snippet: China’s big bet on manufacturing helped to counteract its housing slowdown in the first three months of the year, but other countries are worried about a flood of Chinese goods.
articles.abstract: China’s big bet on manufacturing helped to counteract its housing slowdown in the first three months of the year, but other countries are worried about a flood of Chinese goods.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Chinese economy grew more than expected in the first three months of the year, new data shows, as China built more factories and exported huge amounts of goods to counter a severe real estate crisis and sluggish spending at home.
articles.byline: By Keith Bradsher and Alexandra Stevenson

articles.headline: Microsoft Makes High-Stakes Play in Tech Cold War With Emirati A.I. Deal
articles.snippet: Microsoft said it would invest $1.5 billion in G42, an Emirati company with ties to China, as Washington and Beijing maneuver to secure tech influence in the Persian Gulf.
articles.abstract: Microsoft said it would invest $1.5 billion in G42, an Emirati company with ties to China, as Washington and Beijing maneuver to secure tech influence in the Persian Gulf.
articles.lead_paragraph: Microsoft said on Tuesday that it would make a $1.5 billion investment in G42, an artificial intelligence giant in the United Arab Emirates, in a deal largely orchestrated by the Biden administration to box out China as Washington and Beijing battle over who will exercise technological influence in the Persian Gulf region and beyond.
articles.byline: By Paul Mozur and David E. Sanger

articles.headline: The House Republican Going After Universities on Antisemitism
articles.snippet: Representative Virginia Foxx is a blunt partisan. But her life in rural North Carolina informs her attacks against these schools, starting with whether Harvard is truly “elite.”
articles.abstract: Representative Virginia Foxx is a blunt partisan. But her life in rural North Carolina informs her attacks against these schools, starting with whether Harvard is truly “elite.”
articles.lead_paragraph: Virginia Foxx, the Republican congresswoman from North Carolina, has spent the last few months giving elite schools a hard time.

articles.headline: Ukraine’s Big Vulnerabilities: Ammunition, Soldiers and Air Defense
articles.snippet: The shortages add up to a dire situation for Ukraine in the third year of the war, presenting commanders with near impossible choices on how to deploy limited resources.
articles.abstract: The shortages add up to a dire situation for Ukraine in the third year of the war, presenting commanders with near impossible choices on how to deploy limited resources.
articles.lead_paragraph: Ukraine’s top military commander has issued a bleak assessment of the army’s positions on the eastern front, saying they have “worsened significantly in recent days.”

articles.headline: Supreme Court Appears Skeptical of Using Obstruction Law to Charge Jan. 6 Rioters
articles.snippet: The justices considered the gravity of the assault and whether prosecutors have been stretching the law to reach members of the mob responsible for the attack.
articles.abstract: The justices considered the gravity of the assault and whether prosecutors have been stretching the law to reach members of the mob responsible for the attack.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court seemed wary on Tuesday of letting prosecutors use a federal obstruction law to charge hundreds of rioters involved in the Capitol attack on Jan. 6, 2021.
